CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 5-3;Remainder inadmissible;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE he was arrested and placed in police custody .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ordered that the applicant be detained for DATE on suspicion of having committed fraud as a result of which third parties had disposed of their property , valued at MONEY ( ORG ) , to their detriment . The court based its detention order on a reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed the offence and on the severity of the likely penalty , which gave rise to a fear that the applicant would obstruct the proceedings .
CARDINAL . On an unknown date the applicant lodged an appeal against this decision . On DATE ORG dismissed his appeal .
CARDINAL . Subsequent decisions as to the extension of the applicant ’s pre - trial detention were taken on DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE and on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE a bill of indictment against the applicant and CARDINAL other suspect was lodged with ORG . The applicant was charged with fraud as a result of which third parties had disposed of their property , valued at ORG , CARDINAL , to their detriment .
CARDINAL . Subsequent decisions as to the extension of the applicant ’s pre - trial detention were taken on DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . In principle , in all the above - mentioned decisions the courts relied on the same grounds for detention as those given in the first detention order . In some the courts also referred to the complexity of the case , the need to conduct further investigation , the probable collusion between the applicant and other suspects ( later : the co - accused ) and the probable exertion of unlawful pressure on witnesses by the applicant . In particular , the courts indicated that a high risk of collusion existed since CARDINAL of the suspects still remained at large and his whereabouts had not yet been established .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant appealed against the decisions extending his detention on several occasions . All of his appeals were dismissed .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first hearing was held before ORG . Subsequent hearings were held on DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE . At a hearing on DATE ORG remitted the case to ORG so that shortcomings in the investigation could be corrected .

CARDINAL . On many occasions the applicant requested that his detention pending trial be lifted or that a more lenient preventive measure be applied . Each time his request was dismissed . The decisions to that effect were given by ORG ( on DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE ) or by ORG ( on DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE ) . These decisions relied on a reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed the offence and the severity of the likely penalty , which gave rise to a fear that the applicant would obstruct the proceedings . In some decisions it was stressed that the whereabouts of all the persons involved in committing the offence had not yet been established . Many of the decisions were , however , very laconic ; for example , the decision of CARDINAL DATE included CARDINAL lines of reasoning . The applicant appealed unsuccessfully against those decisions on several occasions .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG decided to apply police supervision in place of pre - trial detention . It also prohibited the applicant from leaving the country . In the reasoned grounds for its decision , it stated that , bearing in mind the progress made in collecting evidence , the risk that the applicant would obstruct the proper conduct of proceedings had ceased to exist . On DATE the applicant was released from detention .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again ordered that the applicant be remanded in custody from DATE until DATE . It justified its decision by a reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed the offence and the severity of the likely penalty . It also referred to the necessity to secure the proper conduct of proceedings .
CARDINAL . The applicant remained detained until DATE as transpires from a document issued by the detention centre on the applicant ’s release .
CARDINAL . Hearings were held on DATE , DATE , CARDINAL DATE , an unknown date in DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG sentenced the applicant to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment and ordered that payments be made to the victims on account of the damage incurred . On DATE the applicant appealed .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the judgment and remitted the case to the first - instance court .
CARDINAL . On DATE , DATE and DATE hearings were held before ORG ( which had assumed jurisdiction of the case ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG sent the case back to ORG so that the applicant ’s case could be joined to that of other defendants in the same proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a hearing .
CARDINAL . NORP The proceedings are pending before ORG .
